Synset.Example: "If it rains much more, we can expect some flooding"
"rain, snow and sleet were falling"
"Vesuvius precipitated its fiery, destructive rage on Herculaneum"
"Bullets were spatting down on us"
"The garden air overnight liquefied into a morning dew"
"When it drizzles in summer, hiking can be pleasant"
"Meteors showered down over half of Australia"
"It has only sprinkled, but the roads are slick"
"Put on your rain coat-- it's pouring outside!"

Synset.Definition: come down as if in sheets
Synset.Example: "The rain was sheeting down during the monsoon"

Synset.Definition: pour as if from a sluice
Synset.Example: "An aggressive tide sluiced across the barrier reef"

Synset.Definition: become covered with a layer of ice; of a surface such as a window
Synset.Example: "When the wings iced up, the pilot was forced to land his plane"

Synset.Definition: be very cold, below the freezing point
Synset.Example: "It is freezing in Kalamazoo"
"It was snowing all night"
"It hailed for an hour"

Synset.Definition: precipitate as a mixture of rain and snow
Synset.Example: "If the temperature rises above freezing, it will probably sleet"
"The sky seemed to flame in the Hawaiian sunset"

Synset.Definition: cause to start burning; subject to fire or great heat
Synset.Example: "Great heat can ignite almost any dry matter"
"Light a cigarette"

Synset.Definition: set fire to; cause to start burning
Synset.Example: "Lightning set afire to the forest"

Synset.Definition: ignite anew, as of something burning
Synset.Example: "The strong winds reignited the cooling embers"

Synset.Definition: put out, as of a candle or a light
Synset.Example: "Douse the lights"

Synset.Definition: start to burn or burst into flames
Synset.Example: "Marsh gases ignited suddenly"
"The oily rags combusted spontaneously"
"The oil well blew out"
"The fire caught"

Synset.Definition: start to burn with a bright flame
Synset.Example: "The coal in the BBQ grill finally lit up"
"The setting sun kindled the sky with oranges and reds"

Synset.Definition: kindle anew, as of a fire

Synset.Example: "The dried grass of the prairie kindled, spreading the flames for miles"

Synset.Definition: put out, as of fires, flames, or lights
Synset.Example: "Too big to be extinguished at once, the forest fires at best could be contained"
"quench the flames"
"snuff out the candles"
"Some life-forms were obliterated by the radiation, others survived"
"The sun burned off the fog"
"We combust coal and other fossil fuels"
"Every star seemed to flare with new intensity"
"The night sky flared with the massive bombardment"
"What star outshines the sun?"

Synset.Definition: throw or flash the light of (a lamp)
Synset.Example: "Shine the light on that window, please"

Synset.Definition: shine with a weak or fitful light
Synset.Example: "Beech leaves shimmered in the moonlight"
"The candle flickered"

Synset.Definition: emit light; be bright, as of the sun or a light
Synset.Example: "The sun shone bright that day"
"The fire beamed on their faces"
"The sky lit up quickly above the raging volcano"

Synset.Definition: ignite quickly and suddenly, especially after having died down
Synset.Example: "the fire flared up and died down once again"
"The summer sun alone can cause a pine to blaze"
"Meteors blazed across the atmosphere"

Synset.Definition: emit or reflect light in a flickering manner
Synset.Example: "Does a constellation twinkle more brightly than a single star?"
"The moon glared back at itself from the lake's surface"

Synset.Definition: reflect light or colors like an opal
Synset.Example: "Distant clouds opalesce like pale brocade"
"raindrops caught in a sunbeam seem to opalesce"

Synset.Definition: suck or take up or in
Synset.Example: "A black star absorbs all matter"

Synset.Definition: attract by using an inexorable force, inducement, etc.
Synset.Example: "The current boom in the economy sucked many workers in from abroad"

Synset.Definition: be bright by reflecting or casting light
Synset.Example: "Drive carefully--the wet road reflects"

Synset.Definition: be or become luminescent; exhibit luminescence

Synset.Example: "Unquarried marble sparkled on the hillside"
"A high tension wire, brought down by a storm, can continue to spark"

Synset.Definition: reflect as if in a mirror
Synset.Example: "The smallest pond at night mirrors the firmament above"
"The sun radiates heat"

Synset.Definition: give off, send forth, or discharge; as of light, heat, or radiation, vapor, etc.
Synset.Example: "The ozone layer blocks some harmful rays which the sun emits"
"the substance scintillated sparks and flashes"

Synset.Definition: emit a cloud of fine particles
Synset.Example: "The chimney was fuming"

Synset.Definition: give off smoke, fumes, warm vapour, steam, etc.
Synset.Example: "Marshes reeking in the sun"

Synset.Definition: emit (as light, flame, or fumes) suddenly and forcefully
Synset.Example: "The dragon shot fumes and flames out of its mouth"
"That tower rays a laser beam for miles across the sky"
"The rain forest was literally steaming"

Synset.Definition: shine intensely, as if with heat
Synset.Example: "The coals were glowing in the dark"
"The candles were burning"

Synset.Definition: burn unsteadily, feebly, or low; flicker
Synset.Example: "The cooling lava continued to gutter toward lower ground"
"The wind blew from the West"
"It breezes most evenings at the shore"
"That gale could set in on us with the next high tide"
"A breeze wafted through the door"
"It was storming all night"
"When it squalls, a prudent sailor reefs his sails"

Synset.Definition: rain, hail, or snow hard and be very windy, often with thunder or lightning
Synset.Example: "If it storms, we'll need shelter"

Synset.Definition: blow hard; be gusty, as of wind
Synset.Example: "A southeaster blustered onshore"
"The flames blustered"

Synset.Definition: be the case that thunder is being heard
Synset.Example: "Whenever it thunders, my dog crawls under the bed"
"Fall weather often overcasts our beaches"
"The sky clouded over"
"The sky cleared after the storm"
"Too much rain may blight the garden with mold"

Synset.Definition: drench or submerge or be drenched or submerged
Synset.Example: "The tsunami swamped every boat in the harbor"
"The river runs dry in the summer"
"The windshield fogged up"
"Without a drenching rain, the forest fire will char everything"

Synset.Definition: cause to burn rapidly and with great intensity
Synset.Example: "care must be exercised when this substance is to be deflagrated"
